content.description: Climb the crack on the left side of the Buoux boulder using the vertical pockets.  Balancy with an interesting topout.
content.location: Just left of the Buoux Problem.

content.description: Often overlooked, and perhaps with good reason, this problem is actually better than it first appears.  Begin on the face left of Buoux Arete and climb up and left into the dihedral feature.  Pull carefully as you gain height as some of the flakes look and feel like they're ready to melt.
content.protection: One crashpad to keep your feet clean.  If you fall from anywhere past the first couple of moves, you'll most likely end up in the tree.
content.location: About 10 feet left of the Buoux Arete.

content.description: Stand start. Balanced climbing to a tough topout.
content.location: The arete 15 feet left of Bowling Ball.

content.description: On the back side of the Buoux boulder there is an obvious offwidth crack (V0) that splits the boulder.  Speed climbs the slab left of the crack.  Tall, with a committing move near the top, this problem is highball for sure but totally classic.  Move left to top out.
content.protection: Put your don't fall cap on.
content.location: Backside of the main Buoux Boulder.

content.description:
Begin with your left hand on a good sidepull and your right on a sloping crimper.  Establish your feet and make one big move up and right to a good edge.  Match the slopey lip and move slightly right to topout.

Not sure if this is an FA but it's worth a go if you've climbed everything else and are waiting for your crew to finish up the Bowling Ball.  Anyone have any info on this: name, grade, etc.?
content.location: About 5 feet left of Bowling Ball.

content.description: Sit start on a right side-pull under-cling crimps and a left hand sloper pinch. Figure out how to pull your but off the ground and make moves into the start of the Boux Stand.
Stand start with right hand on side pull rail and left hand in shallow pocket. Â Climb straight up the face to slopey mantel.
content.location: On the north side of the Buoux Boulder, a few feet to the right of the offwidth crack "Buoux OW".

content.description: Start standing with hands in pockets and climb straight up.  An SDS can be done to this problem making it closer to V7.
content.location: Just right of the vertical pockets that follow the arete on the front face of the Buoux boulder

content.description:
Awesome off-width crack on the opposite side of the Buoux Crack problem.

A little harder, but much shorter than the Buoux Crack.

The crack is flared on one side and provides some unique climbing that's not often seen in Joe's Valley.

Once you get started, you can fit your whole body inside and chicken wing your way up to the top. Gets easier closer to the top.

The rating is rather irrelevant, if you can climb crack, you'll zip up the problem. Otherwise it can easily serve you up a nice slice of humble pie.
content.protection: just a pad or two at the bottom is plenty good.
content.location: Located on the front side of the Buoux boulder. Obvious offwidth crack splitting the boulder in half

content.description: The Buoux Dihedral climbs the corner left of Tradesque.  The landing for this problem is flat if you hit either the upper or lower tier  however a fall halfway between from up high could be disastrous.  Climb with care.
content.protection: Put your don't fall cap on.

content.description: Climb the alluring crack by its left side, using holds on the slab, or make it a bit easier by laybacking or climbing the crack directly. Keep it cool at the topout, the good holds are all there. Classic highball.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter, or just do it - nothing's gonna help that much if you blow the crux moves at the top.
content.location: The huge crack on the backside of the Buoux boulder.

content.description: This problem is just right of the V3 "Buoux Problem".  Climb the boulder using face and arete holds while keeping your feet left of the crack.
content.location: On the buoux boulder, just right of the V3 that climbs the pockets

content.description: This boulder problem seems to be undocumented, yet the chalk indicates people are at least attempting it. This boulder is about 20 feet in front of Bowling Ball on top of the short hill towards the road. The start is the same as Bowling Ball V4 for the opening compression moves, then goes left to a crack with a couple of decent holds that follow on the arete. Some creativity is required to get over there. Get ready for a heinous, slopey topout (separate from the right variation). Full value boulder for a shorty!
content.protection: One large pad or two small ones, a spotter so you don't fall down the hill
content.location: If you're standing in front of Bowling Ball, turn around and you'll see this boulder about 20 feet in front of you, on top of the short hill towards the road.

content.description:
From

Insightful Guide to Bouldering Joe's Valley,

by Isaac Caldiero, "Sit start on sidepull jug, climb straight up on rails to a techy mantle." This boulder is about 20 feet in front of Bowling Ball on top of the short hill towards the road. The most obvious line is a sit start on opposing vertical rail jugs with a compression start. Move up the compression moves and find your way up and right towards the juggy shelf and topout. Quite a good boulder that doesn't have much information on it. Regardless, it seems that it still gets traffic!
content.protection: One pad, a spotter so you don't fall down the hill
content.location: If you're standing in front of Bowling Ball, turn around and you'll see this boulder about 20 feet in front of you, on top of the short hill towards the road.

content.description: Crux is the first two moves.
From Insightful Guide to Bouldering Joe's Valley, by Isaac Caldiero, "Squat start on horizontal edge, traverse right to crimp rail, then climb straight up to slopers at the lip, easy mantle."
content.location: If you're standing in front of Bowling Ball, turn around and you'll see this boulder about 20 feet in front of you, on top of the short hill towards the road. This boulder problem is to the right of Bowling Shoes V4.
